adeò illu&longs;tratur, vt noctu videre queant.

&longs;i qui etiam hominum noctu videant,
ij flaua, ac lucida vuea, vt ob&longs;eruaui, præditi &longs;unt: & ideò interdiù maiorem
Iridem flauum o&longs;tendunt.

&longs;uperficies tandem illius, quæ oculi interiora con­
&longs;picit, nigerrimo colore, quì vel Anatomicorum digitos inficiat, intincta e&longs;t.

Tertia tandem, quæ per P L M N O, incedit Aranea dicitur, e&longs;t enim in­
&longs;tar araneæ tenui&longs;&longs;ima, præ&longs;ertim, quà vuæ E H I F, &longs;upponitur.

hæc præte­
rea globuli M K I N Q, anteriorem partem M H I N, circumue&longs;tit, qui in
ea affixus, non &longs;ecus ac Araneus in &longs;uæ araneæ centro, immobilis hæret.
hæc de tunicis.

Reliqui &longs;unt humores tres, quibus oculus repleatur; po&longs;terius i&longs;tud &longs;pa­
tium P L Q O, humori vitreo ob vitri &longs;imilitudinem dicto, natura attri­
buit: anteriorem oculi &longs;edem inter corneam, & vueam, humor aqueus oc­
cupauit, &longs;ic dictus, quod &longs;it natura limpidi&longs;&longs;imus; quippe qui primus ingre­
dientia rerum &longs;imulacra excipiat.

medium locum, prædictum &longs;cilicet glo­
bulum, quem aranea complectitur, humor chri&longs;tallinus &longs;ibi vindicauit.

hic
quà corneam &longs;pectat &longs;phæricæ e&longs;t figuræ, atque ex hac parte foramen H I,
vueæ, &longs;eu pupillam ob&longs;idet, vt aduentantibus rerum &longs;imulacris &longs;it obuius,
eaque; &longs;i&longs;tat, vnde factum e&longs;t illi quoque pupillæ nomen.

Huic quoque Aranea &longs;i­
mul, & vuea tenui&longs;&longs;imis fibris in orbem connectuntur; quæ connexio non in
ora pupillæ extrema, &longs;ed circa ip&longs;am, vt in circulo D E F, &longs;ecundæ figuræ:
qui fibrarum circulus apparet etiam in vuea, e&longs;t enim veluti &longs;utura quædam
circularis circa pupillam, non longè tamen ab ip&longs;a.

porrò iunctura hæc
adeò fortis e&longs;t, vt non &longs;ine aliqua vi vuea, & aranea inde à chri&longs;tallino di­
uellantur.
Hæc de oculi fabrica nunc &longs;ufficiant.

PROBLEMATA NONNVLLA
De Oculi Pupilla.
1. Cvr ei Pupillæ nomen inditum e&longs;t?

Admiratione &longs;anè non caret
apud præcipuas linguas, miro quodam con&longs;en&longs;u, idem etymon
obtinere: &longs;cilicet denominatam e&longs;&longs;e ab imaguncula illa, quæ
veluti parua puppa, &longs;eu pupula, &longs;eu pupilla, qualis in figura
&longs;pectatur, perpetuò in paruo hoc vuæ circello &longs;pectatur.

propter hanc igitur
puppam Hebræi circellum G B I, Bath, ide&longs;t filiolam, Græci korhn, ide&longs;t puel­
lam, Latini demum pupillam cognominarunt.
2. Atqui vnde imaguncula hæc, quæ in oculis no&longs;tris perpetuò &longs;pectatur?

&longs;cilicet ob ter&longs;itiem, & &longs;phæricitatem cornea e&longs;t in&longs;tar conuexi &longs;peculi, quod
&longs;pectanti imaginem reddat, quam ergò videmus in aliorum oculis puppam,
no&longs;tra e&longs;t imago, quæ propterea tamen parua e&longs;t, quoniam oculus &longs;peculum
paruum, ac conuexum &longs;imul e&longs;t, cuius e&longs;t imagines rebus ip&longs;is multò mino­
res reflectere.
vt in tractatu de Speculis optici demon&longs;trant.

3. Cùm tota cornea, quæ Iris maior e&longs;t, &longs;it æquè tor&longs;a, ac perpolita, cur
non æquè tota hanc pupulam o&longs;tendit?

&longs;ed è regione minoris Iridis ferè tan­
tum?

cau&longs;a e&longs;t in promptu, quia nimirum &longs;peculum debet e&longs;&longs;e omnis colo­
ris expers, ne colores &longs;peculi coloribus imaginum mi&longs;ceantur; tali&longs;que e&longs;t
Iris minor,quæ etiam&longs;i videatur nigra, non tamen verè colorata e&longs;t, vt mox
o&longs;tendam: at verò maiori Iridi colores vueæ &longs;ub&longs;unt, qui ne &longs;peculi officio
fungatur, &longs;unt impedimento.

e&longs;t præterea Iris minor admodum opacata,
quæ altera conditio, maximè &longs;peculo nece&longs;&longs;aria e&longs;t: illa enim nigredo Iri­
dis minoris, &longs;eu pupillæ, non nigredo, &longs;ed opacitas e&longs;t, vt dicetur po&longs;tea.

4. Cùm iam con&longs;tet foramini vuæ G H I, à pupilla in ip&longs;o ver&longs;ante nomen
inditum e&longs;&longs;e; nec non vnde &longs;it ea pupilla, & cur tam parua; quæritur iam,
quid &longs;it pupilla, &longs;eu Iris minor, an &longs;cilicet &longs;it foramen illud vueæ, an potius
chri&longs;tallinus humor, qui in illud intruditur, vacuumque; illius replet?

Re­
&longs;pondeo, Ari&longs;t. humorem ip&longs;um chri&longs;tallinum appella&longs;&longs;e pupillam: Galenum
tum chri&longs;tallinum, tum foramen ip&longs;um: aptè tamen vtrumque dici exi&longs;timo.

Chri&longs;tallinum quidem & quia replet vacuum illud, atque è regione illius pu­
pillæ imaguncula &longs;pectatur.

foramen verò, quia terminos illius rotunditatis
circum&longs;cribat.

vnde aptius fortè dixeris, vtrumque, chri&longs;tallinum &longs;cilicet,
& foramen veluti partes ad totam pupillam con&longs;tituendam e&longs;&longs;e nece&longs;&longs;aria:
ita vt nihil aliud ip&longs;a &longs;it, quàm &longs;uperficies illa chri&longs;tallini; quæ vueæ fora­
mine continetur.
5. Cur in omnibus hominibus nigra videtur?

cum tamen nigri nihil ibi
e&longs;&longs;e ex anotomia con&longs;tet: imò ibi chri&longs;tallinus e&longs;t omninò pelluidus; & vl­
tra, citraque; alij duo humores, vitreus, & aqueus, æquè tran&longs;parentes, atque
omnis nigredinis expertes.
vnde igitur nigredo illa?

Dicendum e&longs;t nigre­
dinem hanc non e&longs;&longs;e veram, &longs;ed apparentem, eamque; ex interna oculi opa­
citate; opacitatem verò ex foraminis paruitate, quæ lumen non admittat,
prouenire: quotidiana enim nos docet experientia fene&longs;tellas, & huiu&longs;modi
alia foramina, quæ intus non &longs;int illuminata, &longs;ed tenebro&longs;a, nigra quamuis
minimè &longs;int, apparere.

Idem præterea mihi ex anatome manife&longs;tè patuit,
cùm enim per &longs;ectionem ca&longs;u quodam pupilla oculi, quem &longs;ecabam, facta
fui&longs;&longs;et aliquanto mior, illicò nigredine omni exuta, alba vi&longs;a e&longs;t; quia &longs;ci­
licet patuit lumini aditus, quod internam oculi opacitatem fugauit.

pro­
pterea in bobus, & capris, quia magna, & oblonga e&longs;t, quæ multum lucis
admittat, aloa &longs;imiliter, non vt in nobis nigra con&longs;picitur.
6. Cur in clari&longs;&longs;ima luce Solis pupilla omninò euane&longs;cit?

ex dictis in præ­
cedenti problemate, huic quoque &longs;atisfieri pote&longs;t.

cùm enim clari&longs;&longs;imo lumi­
ni obijcitur, fit, vt oculi interiora illu&longs;trentur; vnde fugatis tenebris, & om­
ni opacitate, etiam nigredo illa nulla &longs;it.

7. Po&longs;&longs;umus ne dum in oculos alterius intuemur, quanta &longs;it re vera, co­
gno&longs;cere?

exi&longs;timo certam ip&longs;ius quantitatem oculos no&longs;tros omninò late­
re: videtur enim per refractionem, cùm &longs;it infra humorem aqueum aere
den&longs;iorem, at quæ refractè videntur ex medio den&longs;iore, ea maiora, quàm
&longs;int, apparere, demon&longs;trant Per&longs;pectiui.

attamen cùm in luce &longs;atis tempe­
rata ver&longs;amur, &longs;i oculum directè, vt minor fiat refractio, &longs;pectemus, ip&longs;am
non multò verò maiorem &longs;pectabimus.

8. Sed vnde nam illud mirum illi accidit, vt modo maior, modo minor
nullo fermè tempore interpo&longs;ito, euadat; & aliquando ad tantam magni­
tudinem exere&longs;cat, vt totam forè maiorem Iridem occupet; vt &longs;i in &longs;ecun­
da figura foramen B G I, v&longs;que ad circulum L M N O, dilataretur?

Antiquio­
res, vt Galenus, cùm ob&longs;erua&longs;&longs;ent eam, multò maiorem e&longs;&longs;e noctu, quam
interdiù, id &longs;olummodo ratione noctis, & diei contingere, atque foramen il­
lud verè augeri, & minui exi&longs;timarunt.

&longs;u&longs;pen&longs;um tamen Galenum reddit,
nulla huius motus organa reperiri, qua propter ad &longs;piritus animales confu­
git, eisque; huius augmenti, & decrementi cau&longs;am attribuit: eiu&longs;dem &longs;enten­
tiæ e&longs;t 10. Bapti&longs;ta Porta, inter huius ætatis Per&longs;pectiuos celebris.

Hiero­
nymus ab Aquapendente ab antiquioribus in eo di&longs;&longs;entit, quod cau&longs;am hu­
ius referat non in &longs;piritus, &longs;ed in proprietatem quandam ip&longs;ius vueæ natu­
ralem.

Porrò cum ego &longs;ententias horum mente ver&longs;arem opportunè acci­
dit, vt vel ip&longs;o meridie cùm quodam in loco &longs;atis opaco colloquerer, atque
eo illius capitis &longs;itu, vt oculi illius in multa e&longs;&longs;ent opacitate, cùm ecce tibi
pupillas illius, magna cum admiratione, adeò magnas con&longs;pexi, vt totam
ferè maiorem Iridem adæquarent; illicò hominem in claram lucem, atque
Solem deduxi; atque ecce tibi repentè eædem pupillæ minimæ factæ &longs;unt.

eandem &longs;ubinde experientiam &longs;excenties ob&longs;eruaui, vnde duo notatu di­
gna innotuerunt.

Primum e&longs;t: Maiores no&longs;tros hallucinatos e&longs;&longs;e cùm nocte tantummodo
magnas, per diem verò paruas fieri pupillas opinati &longs;unt: Verum id ratio­
ne lucis, & tenebrarum quouis tempore accidere patuit.

vnde etiam in ob­
&longs;curi&longs;&longs;ima nocte admota oculis accen&longs;a candella, minuantur; amota &longs;tatim
augeantur.

hinc accidit, pupillam hanc, Medicum quendam ætate no&longs;tra
celebrem fefelli&longs;&longs;e, quì dum ægrotum quendam in cubiculo &longs;atis tenebro&longs;o,
oculisque; laborantem curaret, animaduertit illius pupillas e&longs;&longs;e iu&longs;to maio­
res, quapropter plurima illi medicamenta pro pupillarum re&longs;trictione ad­
hibuit; &longs;ed omnia tamen irrita; cui ad mota luce, &longs;tatim &longs;unt imminutæ:
nec tamen æger conualuit.
erat &longs;cilicet apparentia, non veritas.
Secundum hoc modo patuit.

C&etail;peram namque pariter de principali quæ­
&longs;tione ambigere circa &longs;ententiam eorundem, num &longs;cilicet verè pupillæ mo­
dò dilatarentur, modò con&longs;tringerentur; an potius aliqua &longs;it, quæ eos fe­
fellerit apparentia.

atque tandem po&longs;t diuturnam ob&longs;eruationem, po&longs;t plu­
rimorum oculorum di&longs;&longs;ectionem, tutò au&longs;us &longs;um primò a&longs;&longs;erere, pupillas ve­
rè nec augeri, nec minui, &longs;ed meram illam e&longs;&longs;e apparentiam, quod &longs;equen­
tibus rationibus comprobabam.

Primò, &longs;i verè tunc cum fermè maiorem totam Iridem occupant, relicta
tantummodo gracili in orbem armilla, dilatarentur, tunc nece&longs;&longs;ariò con­
nexio vueæ cum aranea &longs;cinderetur, cùm tunc pupillæ gyrum D E F, illius
connexionis ve&longs;tigium tran&longs;cendant; ac præterea tenui&longs;&longs;imæ illæ fibræ, qui­
bus con&longs;uitur, frangerentur, &longs;tatimque; iterum nemine auctore re&longs;arcirentur.

quod nec &longs;ine oculi detrimento, nec &longs;ine &longs;en&longs;u doloris aliquo fieri po&longs;&longs;e, quis
dicat?
quæ omnia nullo modo con&longs;equuntur.

Secundò, nulla extant huius organa motus, quod plures Anatomicos,
atque Galenum ip&longs;um dubios reddit.

Tertiò, Medici omnes volunt eos, qui angu&longs;tiori &longs;unt pupilla, acie ocu­
lorum plus valere, quàm qui &longs;unt latiori; &longs;i ergò i&longs;ta e&longs;&longs;et vera con&longs;trictio,
& dilatatio, accideret nos eodem p&etail;nè temporis momento, modò acutius,
modò hebetius videre: imò in temperata luce, vbi maior apparet, minus,
quam in clari&longs;&longs;ima luce, & Sole, vbi minima apparet, videremus.

quibus
quotidiana refragatur experientia.

Quartò, plura obiecta compræhenderet oculus in opacitate, quàm in cla­
ritate, & Sole: omnia enim illa videmus, quæ intra pyramidem vi&longs;ualem
continentur, quæ eò capacior, & latior e&longs;t, quò pupilla maior e&longs;t: habet
namque hæc pyramis verticem in centro oculi, & po&longs;tea dilatatur ad dilata­
tionem foraminis vueæ, quod e&longs;t pupilla.

verùm nos nunquam experimur
plura obiecta compræhendere in vmbra, quam in Sole.

Quintò, &longs;i illa dilatatio vera e&longs;&longs;et, pupilla non &longs;emper in homine videre­
tur nigra; magnitudo enim foraminis multum luminis intra oculum admit­
teret, quod opacitatem, & nigredinem illam omnem fugaret; hac enim de
cau&longs;a in bobus, & capris alba cernitur.

quapropter certò certius, & luce
clarius, motum hunc non verum, &longs;ed apparentem e&longs;&longs;e mihi, atque alijs per­
&longs;uadebam.

Verumenimuerò Græcorum illud adagium, &longs;ecundæ cogitationes &longs;unt
&longs;apientiores, veri&longs;&longs;imum e&longs;t, nam quinquennio po&longs;tquam hæc de pupillæ di­
latatione con&longs;crip&longs;eram, cùm iterum opticam publicè aggrederer, oculi
fabricam, atque pupillæ motum i&longs;tum attentius con&longs;iderans, conatus &longs;um ob
&longs;equentes rationes prædictis euidentiores mutare &longs;ententiam, atque a&longs;&longs;erere
verè pupillam augeri, ac minui, eò quod vuea ip&longs;a in luce verè con&longs;tringa­
tur, in opacitate verò, ac tenebris magno naturæ miraculo dilatetur.

Prima ratio, cùm pupilla minuitur, eam perpetuò vue&etail; colores con&longs;equun­
tur, eamque; circundant, &longs;iue cum ip&longs;a con&longs;tringuntur; quod minimè fieret,
ni&longs;i vuea ip&longs;a con&longs;tringeretur, &longs;icque, foramen illud imminueret.

Secunda, ex hac experientia; fac vt aliquis alterum &longs;ibi oculum manum
illi applicans tegat: & illicò &longs;ine vlla lucis mutatione videbis alterius ocu­
li pupillam modicùm, &longs;ed tamen &longs;en&longs;ibiliter &longs;atis dilatari.

Tertia, animalia quædam, vt Catus, quando pupillam &longs;uam hanc dila­
tant, eam in orbem dilatant: quando verò con&longs;tringunt, eam in oualem, ac
tandem rimulam quandam con&longs;tringunt: idque; in eadem opacitate, quæ ar­
gumento &longs;unt vueam ip&longs;am moueri.

Quarta, e&longs;t quidam oculorum morbus, quo æger ab&longs;que magno dolore lu­
cem nequit a&longs;picere: ergò &longs;ignum lucem aliquid intra oculum mouere po&longs;­
&longs;e, ex quo motu æger doleat; huiu&longs;modi ægrotum quendam ego aliquando
magna admiratione inui&longs;i.

hæc adeò miranda in nobis &longs;ummus naturæ opi­
fex perpetuò operatur.

Reliquum e&longs;t, vt &longs;uperioribus rationibus, quibus me diù deceptum fui&longs;&longs;e
exi&longs;timo, &longs;atisfaciam.

Ad primam igitur re&longs;pondeo, etiam&longs;i vuea verè dilatetur, non indè ne­
ce&longs;&longs;ariò &longs;equi connexionem illam &longs;cindi debere: po&longs;&longs;unt enim tenui&longs;&longs;imæ il­
læ fibræ intendi, ac remitti: &longs;icque; motui vueæ obtemperare.

Ad &longs;ecundam, cau&longs;am efficientem huius dilatationis e&longs;&longs;e &longs;piritus; non
partem quampiam, aut organum materiale.
Ad tertiam negandum e&longs;t illud Medicorum placitum.

Ad quartam concedenda e&longs;t tota, &longs;ed tamen addendum e&longs;t, nos non ad­
uertere modò plura obiecta, modò pauciora videre, quia valde difficile e&longs;t
id ob&longs;eruare, porrò fateor difficile e&longs;&longs;e huic rationi &longs;atisfacere, quia non,
omninò con&longs;tat, qua ratione, & quo loco oculi fiat vi&longs;io.

Ad quintam dicendum e&longs;t, nunquam foramen illud pupillæ ad tantam ma­
gnitudinem euadere, vt &longs;atis lucis admittat ad oculi internam opacitatem
fugandam.

Præterea, quando dilatatur e&longs;t in loco &longs;atis opaco, vnde fit, vt
opacitas ambientis aeris minimè expellat oculi opacitatem; quin potius
eam iuuet nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t.
9. Cur altero oculorum tecto, alterius pupilla aliquantulum dilatatur?

R. &longs;ciendum miram e&longs;&longs;e oculorum &longs;ocietatem, quò vnus intuetur, alter eò
etiam con&longs;pirat: quor&longs;um alter conuertitur, eor&longs;um & alter: anima enim
vtitur duobus oculis tanquam vno.

quia igitur dum alter tegitur, ei &longs;imul
tenebræ offunduntur, quibus præ&longs;entibus pupilla illius ampliatur, vt &longs;upra
vidimus, nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t, ob oculorum fidam &longs;ocietatem, vt alterius etiam pu­
pilla augeatur.

huic re&longs;pon&longs;ioni quis in hunc modum obijciet: cùm alter ocu­
lus &longs;it in lumine, ac eapropter pupillam con&longs;tringere debeat; cur non ei po­
tius alter morem gerit, &longs;icque; pupillam, præ&longs;entibus etiam tenebris in &longs;uo
&longs;tatu continet.

huic iterum re&longs;pondeo, quoniam alter, qui obtenebratur pu­
pillam ampliare, alter verò, qui illuminatur coarctare &longs;tudet, fit vt vterque
pupillam, modicum tamen, vt experientia docet, in orbem diducat.

Atque hæc &longs;unt, quæ nuper circa oculi pupillam ob&longs;eruata, huic loco ad­
denda exi&longs;timaui.

primum quidem, vt mei perpetui erga te

tu enim cùm Phy&longs;iologiæ,
ac Mathematicarum omnium Encyclopædiam mirum,
in modum excolueris, ad intima Mathematicarum pene-
tralia ita perua&longs;isti, vt Archimedis, & Apollonÿ ad­

Quanta porrò in rebus agendis prudentia valeas toti penè

&longs;olùm ad omnes ferè Italiæ, atque Germaniæ Principes,

DE NATVRA SCIENTIARVM
MATHEMATICARVM.

ram &longs;pectantia &longs;par&longs;im dicta &longs;unt, non ab re, neque ingratum

De&longs;ubiecto Geometræ, & Arithmeticæ, quod &longs;olet dici
Materia intelligibilis.

Primò, agemus de puris Mathematicis Geometria, & Arithmetica,

Quantitas igitur ab&longs;tracta à materia
&longs;en&longs;ibili dupliciter con&longs;iderari &longs;olet.

con&longs;ideratur enim à Phy&longs;ico,

à Geometra verò, & Arithmetico con&longs;idera­

quantitate etiam di&longs;creta, &longs;eu in numeris proportionaliter reperiuntur,

Vnde manife&longs;tum e&longs;t, has affectiones, quas Ma­

&longs;ed addita Quantita­

Quapropter inrè di­
xeris formalem rationem Mathematicæ con&longs;iderationis e&longs;&longs;e Terminatio­
nem; & obiectum totale adæquatum e&longs;&longs;e Quantitatem terminatam, qua­
tenus terminata e&longs;t.

Ex hac enim terminatione variæ oriuntur figuræ, &
numeri, quas Mathematicus definit, deque; ip&longs;is varia demon&longs;trat.

Atque hæc
e&longs;t illa Quantitas, quæ dici &longs;olet materia intelligibilis, ad differentiam ma­

&longs;eparatur, ac &longs;olo intellectu percipitur.

Continuum igitur, & di&longs;cretum,
vtrumque terminatum, e&longs;t materia intelligibilis, illud Geometriæ, i&longs;tud Arith­
meticæ.

Hinc etiam patet, cur dicatur Mathematicus con&longs;iderare Quan­
titatem finitam, quia accipit terminatam, quæ finita e&longs;t: quod enim habet

quod &longs;i dari po&longs;&longs;et quantitas aliqua termi­

&longs;i enim daretur triangulum infinitum, eodem modo de eo o&longs;tendi po&longs;&longs;et ha­

tatem e&longs;&longs;e Geometriæ, & Arithmeticæ &longs;ubiectum minimè cognouerunt ij,

Porrò ex hac mathematica ab&longs;tractione à materia &longs;en&longs;ibili, fit vt materia

v. g. triangulum ab&longs;tractum e&longs;t omninò planum ex tri­

riri po&longs;&longs;e.

vnde nonnulli &longs;olent Mathematicis illud obijcere; entia &longs;cilicet
mathematica non extare, ni&longs;i per &longs;olum intellectum.

dum e&longs;t entia hæc mathematica, quamuis in ea perfectione non extent, id

Ars præterea palàm
magis ea&longs;dem figuras pro&longs;equitur; artifices enim omnia ferè opificia qua­

Verum ip&longs;a
quoque ars, non &longs;ecus ac natura, quam imitatur &longs;uo fine ob materiæ rudita­
tem defraudatur.

Quamuis igitur re ip&longs;a non exi&longs;tant, quia tamen tamin
mente Auctoris naturæ, quàm in humana, eorum Ideæ tamquam exacti&longs;&longs;i­

agit Mathematicus.

Quapropter dicendum e&longs;t, entia hæc Geometrica om­
nibus numeris ab&longs;oluta e&longs;&longs;e entia per &longs;e, & vera; figuræ verò tum natura­

v. g. triangulum in aliqua
charta depictum, non e&longs;t verum triangulum, &longs;ed verum triangulum illud e&longs;t,
quod in idæa diuina e&longs;t.

ex quibus obiter illud intelligas, cur &longs;cilicet ali­
quando Plato dixerit Deum geometrizare, ide&longs;t tanquam verum Geome­

tæ, quì res perfectas imitari debent, eas &longs;altem vt plurimum, non vt exti­

ad obie­

Similiter aliquando plures anguli partiales componunt tanquam mate­

quæ quidem materiæ accep­

Analyticis de &longs;cientiarum principijs loquitur, inter ea definitiones Geome

& rei, & nominis expo&longs;itiones.

quod &longs;æpè accidit, cùm &longs;cilicet nomina val­

tales &longs;unt &longs;æpè
nomina, & definitiones Geometricæ.

Exempli cau&longs;a, talis e&longs;t definitio qua­
drati, nam quando dico, quadratum e&longs;t figura plana quatuor rectis lineis,
& quatuor angulis rectis con&longs;tans, explico &longs;imul rationem nominis, & ra­

Explico deinde
totam eius e&longs;&longs;entiam, quando dico ip&longs;um con&longs;tare ex quatuor lineis rectis,
& quatuor angulis rectis, quæ duo &longs;imul iuncta con&longs;tituunt totam quadrati
e&longs;&longs;entiam, &longs;unt enim ip&longs;ius differentia con&longs;titutiua; loco autem generis e&longs;t
figura plana quadrilatera: quapropter erit hæc perfecti&longs;&longs;ima definitio, cùm
non &longs;olum nominis, &longs;ed etiam rei e&longs;&longs;entiam rotam patefaciat; &longs;tatim enim,
ac cogno&longs;cimus quadratum ex prædictis con&longs;tare nihil amplius de ip&longs;ius e&longs;­
&longs;entia animus &longs;cire de&longs;iderat, &longs;ed acquie&longs;cit, vnde eam e&longs;&longs;e optimam defi­
nitionem manife&longs;tum e&longs;t.

Huiu&longs;modi quoque e&longs;t definitio figuræ altera par­
te longioris, nam cùm dicitur, ea e&longs;t figura plana quadrilatera, quæ rectan­

amplius de ea quærendum &longs;uper&longs;it.

Similiter cum dicitur, æquilaterum trian­
gulum e&longs;t, quod tria latera habet æqualia, ecce tibi, & nominis, & rei cau­
&longs;a.

talis e&longs;t etiam prima 6. definitio, &longs;imiles figuræ rectilineæ &longs;unt, quæ & an­

talis

innumeras huiu&longs;modi alias, quæ apud alios Geo­

&longs;ed alias
contemplemus, quæ nullo modo &longs;unt nominis definitionis, &longs;ed rei tantum,

habet enim e&longs;&longs;e partim ab&longs;olutum, partim relatiuum; cùm in prima defi­
nitione dicitur.

Punctum e&longs;t, cuius nulla pars e&longs;t, definitur quatenus ab&longs;o­
lutum, cùm po&longs;tea in tertia definitione dicitur, termini lineæ &longs;unt puncta,
definitur quatenus e&longs;t quid alterius: ex quibus tota puncti natura fit mani­
fe&longs;ta; etymologia verò ne quaquam; nam dicitur punctum à pungendo, qua&longs;i
&longs;it punctura quædam, quæ notio in Euclidis definitione minimè attingitur.

Similiter cum dicitur, line a e&longs;t longitudo latitudinis expers, vbinam nomi­
nis ratio?

nam linea dicitur à lino, qua&longs;i lineum filum; antiquitus enim ex
lino fila fiebant, quibus fabri ad de&longs;ignationes vtebantur, quemadmodum
nunc ex cannabe: at in Euclidis definitione ridiculum e&longs;t hanc rationem que­
rere; in qua tamen lineæ e&longs;&longs;entia perfectè apparet.

Pariter quando definit &longs;uperficiem e&longs;&longs;e eam, quæ longitudinem, latitudi­
nemque; tantum habet, apparet quidem rei natura, at verò vbi nominis defi­
nitio, quæ e&longs;t, dici &longs;uperficiem, qua&longs;i &longs;upremam faciem?

Cùm dicitur An­
gulus e&longs;t duarum linearum, &longs;e mutuò tangentium inclinatio, vbinam vocis
notio?
aperitur tamen rei natura, & quidditas.

Sed magis manife&longs;tum e&longs;t
in linea perpendiculari, quæ proculdubio denominata e&longs;t à perpendiculo,
in definitione tamen nullum huius ve&longs;tigium: at verò quid ip&longs;a &longs;it, optimè
explicatur.

Definitio porrò circuli videtur a&longs;&longs;ignari non per intrin&longs;eca,
&longs;ed tamen æquiualet intrin&longs;ecæ definitioni; quando enim dicitur circulus
e&longs;t figura plana, vncia linea contenta, ad quam ab vno puncto eorum, quæ
intra figuram &longs;unt, ductæ omnes lineæ &longs;unt æquales, perinde e&longs;t, ac &longs;i dice­
ret, circulus e&longs;t figura plana, cuius medium æquidi&longs;tat ab extremis, qu&etail; e&longs;t
e&longs;&longs;entialis; po&longs;ita enim hac æquidi&longs;tantia, ponitur nece&longs;&longs;ariò circulus.

Ve­
rùm centri definitionem e&longs;&longs;e tantum nominis explicationem; ab&longs;urdum e&longs;t:
centrum enim vox gr&etail;ca e&longs;t, quæ primo &longs;ignificat &longs;timulum, vel aculeum il­
lum.
quo Boues agit bubulcus.

At Rhombi definitionem, quàm ridiculum e&longs;t, eam nominis &longs;olum expli­
cationem continere, cùm nihil minus.

Dicitur enim Rhombus à cuiu&longs;dam
pi&longs;cis, vel cuiu&longs;dam textorij in&longs;trumenti &longs;imilitudinem, cuius figuram refert.

naturam tamen ip&longs;ius definitio aperit, ide&longs;t Rhombus e&longs;t figura plana qua­
drilatera, æquilatera, &longs;ed non rectangula.

Idem per&longs;picere licet in defini­
tionibus corporum, quarum prima e&longs;t, &longs;olidum e&longs;t, quòd longitudinem, la­
titudinem, & cra&longs;&longs;itudinem habet; ex qua clarè tota rei natura per&longs;picitur.

Sed ne longior &longs;im, innumeras pene alias apud omnes Geometras reperies
omnino e&longs;&longs;entiales, quas prætero: eadem pror&longs;us de Arithmetic&etail; defini­
tionibus &longs;unt intelligenda, vt eas con&longs;ideranti &longs;tatim patebit.

Quod &longs;i quis
iam fateatur ha&longs;ce definitiones e&longs;&longs;entiales e&longs;&longs;e, &longs;ed tamen adhuc Mathema­
ticis illas definitiones cau&longs;ales, quas demon&longs;tratio requirit, deneget; is &longs;i­
bi refragrantem audiat Ari&longs;t. qui tex. 12. 2. de Anima; ait Tetragoni&longs;mi
extare duas definitiones, vnam formalem, &longs;eu e&longs;&longs;entialem, qu&etail; e&longs;t, Tetrago­
ni&longs;mus e&longs;t effectio quadrati æqualis dato æquilatero; altera verò cau&longs;alis,
&longs;cilicet Tetragoni&longs;mus e&longs;t inuentio medi&etail; proportionalis, quia linea illa me
dia proportionali, e&longs;t cau&longs;a quadrati æqualis datæ figuræ: vide no&longs;tram hu­
ius loci explicationem.

Concedat is igitur oportet, Geometricas de fini­
tiones non &longs;olum nominales, &longs;ed etiam formales, & cau&longs;ales e&longs;&longs;e.

quo no­
mine Mathematicas definitiones reliquarum &longs;cientiarum definitiones an­
tecellere iam certum e&longs;&longs;e pote&longs;t; cùm apud omnes Philo&longs;ophos in confe&longs;&longs;o
&longs;it, vltimas rerum differentias nos latere, &longs;ine quibus vera definitio nulla e&longs;t;
adeò, vt etiam apud eo&longs;dem ambigatur, vtrum illa definitio hominis, ani­
mal rationale, vera &longs;it definitio nec ne.

Obijces fortè iterum, definitiones ha&longs;ce Mathematicarum e&longs;&longs;e vt pluri­
mum definitiones &longs;ubiecti: at in poti&longs;&longs;ima demon&longs;tratione, ad quam tendi­
mus, requiri cau&longs;ales definitiones pa&longs;&longs;ionis primò, & per &longs;e; definitionem
verò &longs;ubiecti per accidens, vt quando aliquid immediatè ab ea procedens
de &longs;ubiecto ip&longs;o demon&longs;trandum e&longs;t.

re&longs;pondendum cen&longs;eo, primò, quod cùm
definitio cau&longs;alis pa&longs;&longs;ionis non &longs;it aliud, quam cau&longs;a ip&longs;ius, &longs;i in definitione
&longs;ubiecti continetur causa pa&longs;&longs;ionis, a&longs;&longs;umendo definitionem &longs;ubiecti, a&longs;&longs;u­

eam formalem, alij realem, alij modalem, alij ex natura
rei, alij realem modalem, & alij alijs formalitatibus eam appellant; qui­
bus &longs;ingulis aliquam realitatem illi ine&longs;&longs;e &longs;ignificant, quæ &longs;ufficit ad per&longs;e­
ctam demon&longs;trationem.

&longs;atis enim e&longs;t ad perfectam demon&longs;trationem, vt
per eam cau&longs;a propria, & adæquata effectus, iuxta rei naturam, detegatur,
&longs;ic enim intellectui no&longs;tro fit &longs;atis, vt acquie&longs;cat, & verum intueatur, quod
e&longs;t finis perfectæ demon&longs;trationis.

neque verò maior, aut minor di&longs;tinctio fa­
cit, vt cau&longs;a &longs;it magis, aut minus vera, &longs;ed vera illa e&longs;t cau&longs;a, quæ verè cau­
&longs;at effectum à &longs;e non ratione tantum di&longs;tinctum: & proinde vera illa demon­
&longs;tratio e&longs;t, quæ pér eam demon&longs;trat.

quartò hæc, quamuis parua di&longs;tinctio,
multum tamen ex alia parte conducit ad demon&longs;trationis perfectionem, ex
ea enim fit, vt in demon&longs;tratione liquidò appareat, cau&longs;am illam e&longs;&longs;e ve­
ram, & propriam affectionis demon&longs;tratæ, ita vt non po&longs;&longs;it à propinquiori
procedere; quod in nulla alia &longs;cientia tam euidenter apparet.

Obiectio 2. Geometra o&longs;tendit eandem conclu&longs;ionem per plures demon­
&longs;trationes, ergò per diuer&longs;a media, atqui vnius effectus e&longs;t vna tantum cau­
&longs;a propria, & adæquata.

Re&longs;pondeo primò, eandem rem o&longs;tendi quidem per plures demon&longs;tratio­
nes, quarum vna e&longs;t à priori, altera verò à po&longs;teriori.

&longs;ecundò, &longs;i omnes &longs;int
à priori, tunc e&longs;&longs;entialiter e&longs;&longs;e vnam tantum, plures verò accidentaliter,
quia in omnibus erit idem medium præcipuum, &longs;ed con&longs;tructio, qua illud
detegitur diuer&longs;a, vt patet in 32. primi, quam aliter Pythagorici, aliter Eu­
clides, aliter Proclus demon&longs;trarunt, &longs;ed tamen in omnibus e&longs;t idem Me­
dium, cau&longs;a &longs;cilicet materialis, quamuis diuer&longs;a &longs;it con&longs;tructio.

Obiectio 3. Demon&longs;trationes Geometricæ non con&longs;tant ex proprijs, &
per &longs;e, non enim Geometra con&longs;iderat e&longs;&longs;entiam Quantitatis, neque eius
pa&longs;siones, quatenus ab illius e&longs;&longs;entia manant, quare ex communibus qui­
bu&longs;dam, & merè extrin&longs;ecis nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t procedere.

Re&longs;pondeo ex dictis cap.
1. de materia intelligibili, & definitionibus Geometricis huic obiectioni
abundè fieri &longs;atis.

materia enim Geometriæ non e&longs;t quantitas &longs;ecundum &longs;e,
&longs;ed quatenus terminata, cuius totam e&longs;&longs;entiam ex definitionibus e&longs;&longs;entiali­
bus Geometra cogno&longs;cit: quorum vtrumque aduer&longs;arios latuit.

Præterea fal&longs;um e&longs;t, Geometram ex communibus pluribus &longs;cientijs pro­
cedere, quod vetat Ari&longs;t. 1. Po&longs;ter. procedit enim ex principijs communi­
bus quantitatibus terminatis, ide&longs;t figuris, & numeris; quod non &longs;olum li­
cet, &longs;ed etiam debet fieri ex 1. Po&longs;ter. tex. 20. & 25. neque vnquam idem prin­
cipium repetit, ni&longs;i vbi e&longs;t effectus formalis ip&longs;ius, & non ni&longs;i contrahendo
ad illud particulare.

Recentiorum calumniæ aduer&longs;us Mathematicas
diluuntur.
Cap. 3.

Prima e&longs;t, qua Alexander Piccolomineus, & eius &longs;ectatores malè con­
tra Mathematicos Proclum adducunt, quod, vt manife&longs;tè videas,
hic tibi de&longs;cribam integram Procli &longs;ententiam, quam ille mutila­
tam citat, & quidem græcè, vt melius lateat.

libro igitur 3. in Eu­
clid. &longs;ic habet: At cau&longs;am, & ip&longs;um Propter quid Geometriam minimè
contemplari pluribus vi&longs;um e&longs;t, huiu&longs;ce enim &longs;ententiæ e&longs;t Amphinomus
Ari&longs;t. duce.

hæc &longs;unt, quæ Piccolomineus græcè citat, quibus deinde &longs;ubdit,
quid amplius quærimus pro hac &longs;ententia?

&longs;ed non ne aduertis Lector, præ­
dictum &longs;ententiam non e&longs;&longs;e Procli, &longs;ed Amphinomi cuiu&longs;dam nullius nomi­
nis philo&longs;ophi, qui &longs;ub falsò Ari&longs;t. patrocinio Geometricæ cau&longs;as auferre
conabatur, quæ tamen ac &longs;i Procli ip&longs;ius e&longs;&longs;et à Piccolomineo in medium,
affertur.

&longs;ed videamus, quæ Piccolomineus prætermi&longs;it, pergit po&longs;tea
Procius, inueniet autem aliquis (inquit Geminus) huius etiam inqui&longs;itio­
nem in Geometria, quo modo Geometræ non e&longs;t quærere qua de cau&longs;a, in
circulis quidem infinita multiangula in&longs;cribantur: in &longs;phæris verò multian­
gula &longs;olida æquilatera, & æquiangula ex &longs;imilibus planis con&longs;tructa infinita
in&longs;cribere e&longs;t impo&longs;sibile.

ad quem enim &longs;pectaret hoc inue&longs;tigare præter
Geometram?

Hæc e&longs;t &longs;ententia Gemini à Proclo allata ad Amphinomi opi­
nionem confutandam.

Pergit po&longs;tea Proclus ex propria &longs;ententia &longs;ic; Quan­
do igitur Geometris &longs;yllogi&longs;mus per impo&longs;sibile fuerit, &longs;ymptoma tàntum
inuenire cupiunt, quando autem per præcipuam demon&longs;trationem, tunc rur­
&longs;us, &longs;i quidem in particulari demon&longs;trationes fiunt, cau&longs;a nondum manife­
&longs;ta e&longs;t, &longs;i verò in vniuer&longs;ali, in omnibusque; &longs;imilibus continuò & ip&longs;um Propter
quid manife&longs;tum e&longs;t.

hæc e&longs;t tota illius loci integra &longs;eries, quàm aduer&longs;arius
mutilatam obtrudebat.
vbi apertè vides, Procli de Geometria &longs;ententiam.

Secunda calumnia e&longs;t, qua contra Mathematicos Ari&longs;t. quamuis inuitum
interpretantur.

neque &longs;olum loca ip&longs;ius clari&longs;sima ex analyticis, phy&longs;icis, &
metaphy&longs;icis, quæ &longs;uperius recitauimus in alienum &longs;en&longs;um detorquent; &longs;ed
præter ea vnicum tantum locum, qui expre&longs;sè Mathematicis refragari vi­
deatur, afferunt, cumque; &longs;ibi falsò fauere confingunt.

is e&longs;t in angulo quodam
operum ip&longs;ius, in &longs;ecundò videlicet Moral. Eudem. cap. 7. &longs;ic, in immobi­
libus autem, vt in Mathematicis non per &longs;e, &longs;ed &longs;imilitudine quadam prin­
cipia appellantur.

cuius germana interpretatio non contra, &longs;ed pro Mathe­
maticis e&longs;t: loquitur enim ibi Ari&longs;t. de principio efficiente, à quo fiunt actio­
nes humanæ, & per motum, vt doceret in homine e&longs;&longs;e principia quarundam
actionum, quæ propriæ &longs;unt hominis, & liberæ.

talia autem principia ne­
gant e&longs;&longs;e in immobilibus, quoniam &longs;unt entia nece&longs;&longs;aria, & libertatis exper­
tia; e&longs;&longs;e tamen &longs;ecundum &longs;imilitudinem, ide&longs;t, vt &longs;e habent principia libera
ad actiones liberas, ita principia nece&longs;&longs;aria ad actiones nece&longs;&longs;arias: vnde
&longs;equitur, quod quemadmodum principia libera &longs;unt adæquata cau&longs;a illarum
actionum; &longs;ic etiam principia Mathematica erunt cau&longs;æ adæquatæ pa&longs;sio­
num Mathematicarum; quod ip&longs;e Ari&longs;t. te&longs;tatur paulo po&longs;t, his verbis: nam
&longs;i habente trigono duos rectos, nece&longs;&longs;e e&longs;t, tetragonum quatuor rectis con­
&longs;tare, clarum e&longs;t, quod trigonus duos rectos habens cau&longs;a eius exi&longs;tit.

& vt
intelligamus eum loqui de propria cau&longs;a, quæ &longs;it medium demon&longs;trationis,
&longs;ubdit; id autem nece&longs;&longs;ariò euenire patet ex analyticis.

quare Mathemati­
cis maximè fauet hic locus, contra quàm aduer&longs;arij autumabant.

nullus igi­
tur locus apud Ari&longs;t. reliquus e&longs;t, qui no&longs;træ &longs;ententiæ apertè non faueat.

Tertia, qua contra Mathematicos Platonem ip&longs;um eximium Mathema­
ticarum fautorem, ac &longs;tudio&longs;um excitare conantur; aiunt enim ip&longs;um 7. de
Rep. dicere Mathematicos circa quantitatem &longs;omniare.

Verùm, ne falla­
cia &longs;ub&longs;it, ecce tibi Platonis verba è græco &longs;yncerè tran&longs;lata.

Reliquæ ve­
rò, quas diximus verarum rerum quoquo modo e&longs;&longs;e participes, Geometriam
&longs;cilicet, eiusque; comites circa ip&longs;am e&longs;&longs;entiam quodammodo &longs;omniant: &longs;yn­
cerè autem quicquam ab illis cernere impo&longs;&longs;ibile e&longs;t, tanti&longs;per dum &longs;uppo­
&longs;itionibus hærent, easque; ratas, & immobiles adeo &longs;eruant, vt illarum ratio­
nem reddere nequeant.

Aduerte primò Platonem non dicere Geometram
ab&longs;olutè &longs;omniare, &longs;ed quodammodo &longs;omniare: deinde non dicere circa
quantitatem, &longs;ed circa e&longs;&longs;entiam: vnde &longs;i liberet funem cum eis trahere
contentio&longs;um, verbisque; hærere, vt ip&longs;i faciunt, nihil contra Mathematicos
facerent.
&longs;ed e&longs;to intelligat ip&longs;am quantitatem, videamus quid &longs;ibi velit.

vt
autem i&longs;tud videamus, &longs;ciendum e&longs;t, totius 7. de Rep. di&longs;cur&longs;um e&longs;&longs;e in con­
&longs;tituendo Reip. Cu&longs;tode, & Gubernatore, quem in primis vult e&longs;&longs;e optimè
natura, tam ad agendum, quàm ad &longs;peculandum idoneum: vult præterea
ip&longs;um &longs;apienti&longs;&longs;imum e&longs;&longs;e, ide&longs;t Theologiam, quàm etiam Dialecticam no­
minat, optimè callere, per quam ab&longs;que vllo di&longs;cur&longs;u rerum, ac præcipuè &longs;um­
mi Boni e&longs;&longs;entias contempletur.

ad hanc diuinam contemplationem, vt
peruenire po&longs;&longs;it, opus ait e&longs;&longs;e eum humanis aliquot di&longs;ciplinis imbutum e&longs;­
&longs;e.

totam autem Philo&longs;ophiam inibi partitur in tres partes, in Dialecticam,
&longs;eu Theologiam, quam intellectui attribuit ab&longs;que vlla &longs;uppo&longs;itione, & di­
&longs;cur&longs;u: hancque; &longs;olam &longs;cientiæ nomine dignam e&longs;&longs;e exi&longs;timat.

&longs;ecundò, in
Mathematicam, quam in cognitione, &longs;eu ratiocinatione collocat, & pro­
pterea principia &longs;upponit.

tertiò tandem in opinionem, quæ ver&longs;atur circa
res naturales, quæ in imaginatione ab eo collocatur.

Iuxta hanc trimem­
brem diui&longs;ionem ex Platonis &longs;ententia &longs;ic habet Mar&longs;ilius Ficinus in argu­
mento huius 7. de Rep.

Diuina &longs;iquidem in tribus aquis repr&etail;&longs;entari viden­
tur, primò quidem licet confu&longs;ius in rationibus phy&longs;icis.

&longs;ecundò, di&longs;tinctius
in Mathematicis.
tertiò, clari&longs;&longs;imè in Metaphy&longs;icis.

& paulo po&longs;t: Diuinas
denique formas omninò immortales, resque; veras Plato exi&longs;timat, quarum,
imagines quidem &longs;unt mathematicæ formæ, vmbræ verò res naturales.

&
po&longs;tea: Cùm autem animaduertat Thaletem, Democritum, Anaxagoram,
tam negligentes in rebus diuinis fui&longs;&longs;e, quàm diligentes in naturalibus; Phæ­
recidem contra, & Pythagoram, Pythagoreosque; omnes Mathematicorum
Principes pariter &longs;ummos extiti&longs;&longs;e Theologos, moribusque; diuinos, meritò
partim ratione, partim experientia conclu&longs;it curio&longs;um naturalium &longs;tudium
animum à diuinis &longs;æpè auertere.

& po&longs;t nonnulla: Quare &longs;eptimus hic liber
de Rep. vbi animum ad &longs;ummum Bonum, Solemque, ide&longs;t Deum, idæasque;
diuinas, qua&longs;i &longs;tellas, conuenientibus producit gradibus, nullam in ip&longs;o
a&longs;cen&longs;u naturalis peritiæ facit mentionem, &longs;ed mathematicos quo&longs;dam gra­
dus ad Diuina commodius perducentes adducit in medium, inter quos duo
&longs;unt puri, Arithmetica, & Geometria, &c.

reliquas deinde Mathematicas
Plato enumerat, ac &longs;ingillatim commendat, atque in Rempub. admittit.

po&longs;t
multa iterum Ficinus &longs;ic, cùm ergò dicit, animam à lucerna ad Lunam, à
Luna ad Solem attolli, &longs;ignificat Plato à formis naturalibus ad Mathemati­
cas, ab his ad diuinas denique eleuari.

& nonnullis intermi&longs;&longs;is, denique Theo­
logiam, quam etiam Metaphy&longs;icam, & Dialecticam dicit, omnibus facul­
tatibus anteponit, vt ducentem omnes, & ad &longs;uum officium vtentem mini­
&longs;terio &longs;ingularum.

officium autem eius e&longs;&longs;e per totam entis progredi latitu­
dinem, atque ad ip&longs;um Bonum totius entis cau&longs;am, &longs;e conferre, & quid vnum­
quodque &longs;it definire, rationem cuiusque; e&longs;&longs;entiæ a&longs;&longs;ignando, quiduè quamlibet
&longs;equatur e&longs;&longs;entiam demon&longs;trare.

Cæteras autem facultates præ huius no­
bilitate iudicat e&longs;&longs;e &longs;eruiles: aut enim ad opiniones hominum declinant, aut
&longs;altem et&longs;i ad incorporea &longs;e &longs;e pro viribus erigunt, nihilominus circa illa
quodammodo &longs;omniant, quales e&longs;&longs;e inquit Mathematicas.

ex quibus iam
clarè vides Platonem dixi&longs;&longs;e Mathematicas quodam modo &longs;omniare circa
e&longs;&longs;entiam rerum, non ab&longs;olutè, &longs;ed comparatione ad Theologiam: intelli­
gis etiam cur Mathematicas nolit &longs;cientias appellari, quia nimirum &longs;olam
Theologiam hoc nomine dignam cen&longs;ebat: qua de cau&longs;a minus Phy&longs;icam,
eodem nomine dignam putauit, cùm eam opinionem, Mathematicam verò
cogitationem, vel ratiocinationem dicat.

ob eandem comparationem a&longs;&longs;e­
rit etiam Mathematicas minus e&longs;&longs;e certas, quam Theologiam, quoniam,
&longs;cilicet hæc nihil &longs;upponit, nihilque; di&longs;currit, &longs;ed intuetur: illæ verò iactis
quibu&longs;dam principijs, quæ probari nequeunt, di&longs;currunt, proptereaque; in
ip&longs;o di&longs;cur&longs;u pote&longs;t error aliquis contingere.

eandem huius loci explica­
tionem habes apud Proclum cap. 10. lib. 1. in Euclid. &longs;ic; Verum quid &longs;ibi
velit Plato, quando in libris de Rep. à Mathematica &longs;cientiæ nomen ab&longs;tu­
lit breuiter dicam.

& paulo po&longs;t; hanc denique &longs;cientiam, quam ab artibus
di&longs;tinguimus diuidens, vnam quidem &longs;uppo&longs;itionis expertem e&longs;&longs;e vult, alte­
ram verò ex &longs;uppo&longs;itione &longs;caturire.

& po&longs;t pauca: & &longs;ic ait Mathematicam
tanquam &longs;uppo&longs;itionibus vtentem ab ea, quæ &longs;uppo&longs;itionibus caret, perfe­
ctaque; e&longs;t &longs;cientia deficere: vna enim verè e&longs;t &longs;cientia, per quam omnia, quæ
&longs;unt cogno&longs;cere apti &longs;umus.

per&longs;picuè igitur vides auctoritate horum phi­
lo&longs;ophorum hæc omnia Platonem non ab&longs;olutè, &longs;ed comparatè dixi&longs;&longs;e.

Po&longs;t hæc Ficinus iterum ex &longs;ententia Platonis &longs;ic pergit: quoniam verò
di&longs;&longs;erendi facultas, &longs;i adole&longs;centibus tradatur opinionem hone&longs;ti debilitat,
vnde euadunt intemperantes, imò & &longs;uperbi, & impij, vt in Philebo quoque,
& legibus dicitur, idcircò ante trige&longs;imum ætatis annum in Mathematicis
erudiendi &longs;unt, atque in publicis negotijs per interualla pariter exercendi.

concludamus tandem hæc pulcherrimo eiu&longs;dem 7. de Rep. loco, quem etiam
Proclus lib. 1. cap. 8. ad verbum ferè &longs;ic recitat: Ideo & in Repub. Socrates
rectè dixit, oculus, nimirum animæ, qui ab alijs &longs;tudijs excœcatur, defodi­
turque; à Mathematicis tantum di&longs;ciplinis recreari, excitarique; rur&longs;us ad eius,
qui e&longs;t, contemplationem, & à &longs;imulacris ad ea, quæ vera &longs;unt: nam pulchri­
tudo, & ordo Mathematicarum rationum, firmitudoque, ac &longs;tabilitas con­
templationis, nos ip&longs;is coniungit intellectibus, perfectèque; in ip&longs;is obfirmat,
perpetuò quidem manentibus, & diuina pulchritudine collucentibus, ac mu­
tuum ordinem &longs;eruantibus.

Animaduerti&longs;ti Lector ex his paucis, quot lau­
dibus in hoc 7. de Repub. Mathematicæ à Platone cumulentur, vt totus ferè
liber quoddam ip&longs;arum encomium videatur: vnde mirum &longs;it, i&longs;tos ex eo­
dem &longs;eptimum locum illum contra Mathematicas, inter tot ip&longs;arum præ­
conia &longs;edulò emendica&longs;&longs;e, ac perperam interpretatos e&longs;&longs;e: &longs;icque Araneos
imitatos e&longs;&longs;e, qui ex mellifluis floribus, ex quibus Apes mella, venenum col­
ligunt.

Verumenimuerò quis vnquam de Platonis mente erga Mathemati­
cas dubitare poterit, cùm ip&longs;e omnes ageometretos è &longs;uo gymna&longs;io reijce­
ret; cùm quotidie, vt ex Philopono refert ip&longs;e Piccolomineus auditoribus
&longs;uis aliquod Problema Mathematicum proponeret.

qui de legibus 6. & 7.
de &longs;ingulis Mathematicis addi&longs;cendis leges &longs;ancit, vbi Geometriam adeò ex­
tollit, vt a&longs;&longs;erat, a&longs;ymetriam quantitatum ignorare, non hominum, &longs;ed por­
corum, ac pecorum ignorantiam e&longs;&longs;e.

In Epinomide tandem quàm digna,
quamque; præclarè de A&longs;tronomia, deque; Geometria, & Arithmetica, quæ ad
eam conferunt, prædicat.

præcipua autem A&longs;tronomiæ laus ibi tradita e&longs;t,
quod ea, inter omnes &longs;cientias, animum ad cœle&longs;tia, atque diuina attollit, in­
deque; ad &longs;ummi Boni cognitionem, atque amorem allicit, quam veram e&longs;&longs;e &longs;a­
pientiam diuinitus inibi Plato pluribus fatetur.

plura alia Platonis loca bre­
uitatis cau&longs;a, prætereo; quis enim, vel leuiter eum attingit, quì non per­
&longs;picuè videat, eum &longs;uper omnes Philo&longs;ophos e&longs;&longs;e Mathematicarum com­
mendatorem eximium.

Quarta e&longs;t Mathematicas, Geometriam pre&longs;ertim con&longs;i&longs;tere in imagi­
natione potius, quàm in di&longs;cur&longs;u, & proinde &longs;cientias e&longs;&longs;e puerilis ingenij,
cùm pueri valeant imaginatione.

accedit authoritas Ari&longs;t. qui 6. Eth. cap. 8,
ait, quid e&longs;t, quòd puer fieri Mathem. pote&longs;t, &longs;apiens, aut naturalis non po­
te&longs;t?
præterea, quia antiquitus pueris ante alias tradebantur.

Re&longs;pondeo,
quòd, vt in præcedenti re&longs;pon&longs;ione dictum e&longs;t ex Plat. &longs;ententia, non ima­
ginatio, &longs;ed ratiocinatio, &longs;eu cogitatio ver&longs;atur circa Mathematicas, ima­
ginatio autem circa naturalem Philo&longs;ophiam; &longs;ed audi Platonem in eodem
&longs;eptimo.

Placet igitur, ait, primam partem vocare &longs;cientiam, &longs;ecundam
cogitationem, tertiam fidem, po&longs;tremam imaginationem.

Con&longs;tat autem
vltimas duas ab ip&longs;o collocari in naturali peritia.

ade&longs;t etiam Procli autho
ritas, qui cap. 5. lib. 1. &longs;ic habet; In&longs;trumentum itaque aptum ad iudicandum
cunctas res Mathematicas cogitationem ex Platonis &longs;ententia &longs;tatuimus,
quippequæ opinione quidem &longs;uperior e&longs;t, ab intelligentia verò &longs;uperatur.

Per cogitationem verò intelligendum e&longs;&longs;e quendam mentis motum, ide&longs;t
di&longs;cur&longs;um, tum ex vi græcè vocis Nohmatos, tum ex vi Latinæ vocis manife­
&longs;tum e&longs;t; cogitatio enim dicitur qua&longs;i coagitatio.

&longs; mentis, quæ idem e&longs;t cùm

Verum quid opus
e&longs;t authoritate, vbi res ip&longs;a videri pote&longs;t, con&longs;ideret quilibet Geometricas

Sed quid dico in nonnullis cùm
totum Euclidis opus &longs;it perpetua quædam illationum catena mirabilis, ita
vt vltimæ ip&longs;ius demon&longs;trationes contineant, &longs;i re&longs;oluantur con&longs;ecutionum
miriadas; at verò omnis illationis expers pror&longs;us e&longs;t imaginatio.

Si verò
ip&longs;arum inuentionem con&longs;ideremus, admirabiles omninò videbuntur, tum
quia res omnino ab&longs;tru&longs;as, & abditas demon&longs;trant, tum quia media, quibus

ca magni Geometræ nomen ei compararunt.

hæc & plura alia non &longs;olum

Cur autem Ari&longs;t. dixerit puerum fieri po&longs;&longs;e Mathematicum
non autem &longs;apientem, aut naturalem, ip&longs;e declarat, quia nimirum in vtraque
eorum opus e&longs;t experientia, quæ in puero non e&longs;t, experientiam enim affert
temporis longitudo: facilius tamen puer moralia intelligit, quam Geome­
trica, facilius enim e&longs;t intelligere quid virtus, quid vitium, &c.

quam quin­
tam, aut &longs;eptimam primi; non ideo tamen puer erit prudens, quia pruden­
tia non &longs;peculatiua, &longs;ed practica e&longs;t, Itaque quod puer &longs;apiens, aut natura­
lis e&longs;&longs;e nequeat, defectus non e&longs;t ex parte intellectus, &longs;ed ex parte experien­
ti&etail;.

Neque præterea dicendæ pueriles &longs;unt, quòd antiquitus, vt vult etiam
Plato, pueris primò traderentur, quandoquidem in illis totius ætatis robur,
& florem in&longs;umebant, cùm ad 30. v&longs;q; ætatis annum in eis, occuparentur.
pueriles meritò dicerentur, &longs;i in pueritia tantùm eis operam dedi&longs;&longs;ent.

Di­
cam &longs;yncerè, quod ip&longs;e, dum eas per plures annos docerem expertus &longs;um;

bus excellebant.

Requirit enim &longs;tudium i&longs;tud omnes ingenij partes, imagi­
nationem, di&longs;cur&longs;um, & memoriam.

ti&longs;ti, quod homines natura Arithmetici ad omnes doctrinas, vt ita dixerim

Quinta, Geometria carpitur, quòd plures habeat demon&longs;trationes per
&longs;uperpo&longs;itionem factas, qui modus demon&longs;trandi videtur aduer&longs;arijs valdè

Secundò, eas e&longs;&longs;e tam perfectas, ac eui­

&longs;et momenti, nec Geometrica, &longs;ed Phy&longs;ica potius, niteretur enim &longs;en&longs;ibus:
&longs;ed &longs;uperponuntur quædam, quæ æqualia &longs;unt, vt ex eorum &longs;uperpo&longs;itione
appareat æqualitas eorum, quæ non &longs;uperponuntur.

Con&longs;idera quartam
primi videbis ibi &longs;uperponi quædam latera æqualia duorum triangulorum,

&longs;ubiecti demon&longs;trationis, &longs;iue trianguli æquilateri definitio:
quare hæc demon&longs;tratio erit per cau&longs;am formalem.

Huius &longs;eculi præcedens pars de&longs;init in anno Dom. 1614. quo ip&longs;a Chro­
nologia pariter ab&longs;oluta e&longs;t.

Atque hic finis e&longs;to breuis huius Chronologiæ, quæ continet auctores ferè
257. annos verò 2464. in 26. &longs;ecula di&longs;tributa; in quam ex antiquis omnes
quot quot reperire potuimus, ex recentioribus &longs;electiores, qui aut &longs;crip­
tis, aut rebus claruerint, cooptauimus; alioquin recen&longs;endi fui&longs;&longs;ent omnes
Pythagorici, atque omnes Platonici, qui omnes Mathematicis eximié naua­
bant operam.

omnes præterea Poetæ ab Homero v&longs;que ad Chri&longs;ti ferè &longs;ecu­
lum annumerandi fui&longs;&longs;ent, erant enim antiquitus poetæ omnes &longs;imul etiam
mu&longs;ici, vt per&longs;picuum e&longs;t ex ijs, quæ in libro de mu&longs;ica Plutarchus in hunc
modum ait; non equidem fui&longs;&longs;e immunem metri, numeriuè rati dictionem
poematum mu&longs;icorum, &longs;ed qualis Stetichori fuit, & veterum aliorum poe­
tarum, qui carmina adhibitis modulis condidere, Terpandrum nanque tra­
dunt adiectis ad &longs;ua, atque Homeri carmina, per &longs;ingulas leges modis, &longs;oli­
tum in ludis cum concertatione editis canere.

Neque mireris, quòd recentes mu&longs;icos omnes, quos Contrapunti&longs;tas appel­
lant, omi&longs;erim, id enim con&longs;ultò, ac meritò feci, cùm mihi ob&longs;equentes ra­
tiones, quas breuiter ex Dialogis de mu&longs;ica Vincentij Galilæi decerp&longs;i,
nomine mu&longs;ici, indigni videantur.

Primò, quia officio mu&longs;ici minimè funguntur: e&longs;t autem ex Platonis, atque
Ari&longs;tot. &longs;ententia, officium mu&longs;ici, rithmis, &longs;iue numeris vti ad auditorum
affectus excitandos: Contrapunti&longs;tæ verò i&longs;ti rithmum omnem, aut nume­
rum a &longs;pernantur.

Secundò, quia &longs;uas illas quatuor, aut quinque partes &longs;ic &longs;imul confundunt,
vt nullum verbum, nullusque; rithmus percipiatur: &longs;ed mera tantummodo
mu&longs;ica quædam confu&longs;io: quam, qui audit ne&longs;cit quid audiat.

Tertiò, quia eodem modo carmina, ac &longs;olutam orationem canunt, vt in­
telligere nequeas carmina ne, an pro&longs;am decantent.

quod quidem maximè
e&longs;t inconueniens, & veteri mu&longs;icæ contrarium.

neque enim mu&longs;ica carminis
numerum offu&longs;care; &longs;ed eum magis exornare, atque viuidum reddere debet.

Quartò, quia cantilenæ &longs;en&longs;um omnem, dum diuer&longs;a verba &longs;imul plures,
in cantu pronunciant, ita tollunt, vt nihil omnino intelligatur: cùm tamen
mu&longs;ici officium &longs;it, cantilenæ &longs;ententiam cantu, & rithmo auditorum ani­
mis ita in genere, vt eos iuxta &longs;ententiæ illius affectum, afficiat, ac commoueat.

Quintò, quia de indu&longs;tria contra leges antiquas repetitiones eiu&longs;dem, vel
con&longs;onantiæ, vel cadentiæ, aut aiunt, atque etiam rithmi maximè vitant: quod
tamen ad animorum motus ciendos plurimùm valet.

Sextò, quia non mu&longs;icè, &longs;ed mimicè, ide&longs;t non rithmis, &longs;ed modis à natu­
ra mu&longs;icæ alienis, ac ridiculis frequenter imitari ge&longs;tiunt.

Hac igitur no&longs;tra qualicunque fruere lucubratiuncula: atque in ea contem­
plare, quo tempore, & à quibus non &longs;olùm Mathematica, &longs;ed aliæ etiam &longs;cien­
tiæ ortum habuerunt: quando & apud quos floruerint, aut de&longs;ierint; ac tan­
dem iterum reuiui&longs;cere c&etail;perint.

Quòd &longs;i quæras, quibu&longs;nam &longs;tudijs, tribus illis annorum millibus, quæ chro­
nologiam hanc no&longs;tram præce&longs;&longs;erunt, homines vacauerint, ac proinde, cur
tam &longs;erò literis operam nauare cæperint: re&longs;pondendum e&longs;&longs;e arbitror,
toto illo tempore homines fui&longs;&longs;e totos, tum in artibus inue­
niendis, atque excolendis, tum in vrbibus, atque
rebus publicis con&longs;tituendis: quippe­
quæ magis humanæ vitæ ne­
ce&longs;&longs;aria erant.

in 2 figura de&longs;ideratur linea P R.
in 2. figura dee&longs;t linea K P:
altera verò, quæ dextror&longs;um vergit, &longs;uperflua e&longs;t.
in figura linea K D L, deberet directè ad punctum A, tendere

p.s: BONONIÆ
Apud Bartholomæum Cochìum.
Superiorum permi&longs;&longs;u.
